threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

threads.com: I'm looking to build a basement bedroom for my kids and I'm wondering about moisture barriers. I just had the area waterproofed, it would get moisture in the corners before but I think that's good now. I know the walls will get moisture and condensation and I've read that the best thing to use is 2" foam boards. Also, I'm confused about whether the wall needs to "breathe" or not. Has anyone insulated a block basement who can tell me what works and what's necessary?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
As a general rule, poor ventilation and circulation is the cause of damp.
Rooms need to breathe.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2513263
Assuming you live in north america:
Google "basement frost wall assembly"
Confirm minimum R-value requirements in local building code
Consider incorporating an air space in your assembly (usually 2.5" min.)
Install poly vapour barrier on warm side of assembly

last_replies.com:
I've done foam board in my basement, with seams taped & a small gap top & bottom for spray foam to create a continuous barrier. That worked fine for eliminating condensation & blocking efflorescence, but I also put drain matt outside so not sure how well it would do if there was heavy water pressure from the outside.

Above that I framed it in with 2x2, pressure treated against the floor, and filled the space between studs with additional 1.5" foam board, then drywall 1/2" off the floor & no trim b/c basements flood.

I've seen the same thing done with an additional vapor barrier directly under the drywall, so I suppose if you really do have a big temp/moisture gradient, you might do that just to be safe.

you're talking about a single phase of the construction of a CPU, the photolithography. the wafers used for this come from somewhere, ready to go. they're held in a stock to be fed into the machine. the photolithography machine itself has been invented and assembled and prepared and maintained. the chemicals used in the process have been prepared and are on-hand.
OP anon was asking about step-by-step "starting from sand" - this is all shit he would need to do manually and prior to the actual etching phase in his scenario that the established industry has the advantage of parallelizing by way of just buying the prepared materials.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2512956
That's hot enough to restore flexibility and close internal cracks. It will lose hardness if it IS a tempered steel but will be the hardest it can be outside of requenching and tempering.

>>2513066
Anything that is carbide forming (tool steels, bearing steels) resists carbon diffusion through martensite (huge Ni/Cr atoms + small Mn/V atoms fug up the diffusion) so you can develop a decorative oxide layer but maintain strength and hardness.

Look for "impact grade" tool steels if you're making a sword.

threads.com: I always assumed that a tiny voltage would have trouble moving through a huge wire. That's why we use small wires for low voltage, right? Yet science tells me that in fact smaller wires have higher resistance so the voltage would actually travel though bigger wire better. Is this true? Would 1v travel better though a huge thick mains voltage cable than a small speaker wire??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507878
Water flows through a pipe voltage mostly moves on the outside of a wire. How are they same?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507876
People are oversimplifying the answering
If you try to put a tiny current through a big wire, it will actually be met with way more resistance than a small wire as the current lacks direction so it can wander around the oversized highway instead of going straight through

Now, this is comparing recommended wire size and wayyy too big wire
If you're not sure what size ones, always go one step up and then use smaller fuses as a wire that's a size too small will have more resistance than a wire that's 2 or 3 sizes too big

When you get beyond those 2 or 3 sizes, though, you start to gain resistance against the current

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508726
>>2510784
>>2509145
Jesus christ. for the purposes of any real conversation DC current flows through the entire cross-section of the conductor. We can be autistic about Maxwell equations all day long about how a conductor cannot have electric field and whatnot, but to go back to the hydraulic analogy that's practically the same thing as arguing that water doesn't flow in a pipe, the pipe just sets the boundaries.

Now, if you were to have a long large diameter wire and a short small diameter wire so that they have equal resistance, and applied the same voltage to them, the larger wire would in fact have the electrons moving slower, but there's more of them so the overall current is the same. In semiconductors (possibly all materials, only really relevant in semiconductors afaik), you will actually run into the limit of the electron drift velocity where increasing voltage does not increase current because the electrons cannot move any faster due to interacting with other shit in the atomic structure

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507876
The simplest explanation is that small wires can't carry a lot of current, so if you want more energy, you raise the voltage or you increase the wire size. Welder cable is an example: it's low voltage, high amperage.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510784
>voltage mostly moves on the outside of a wire.
In most cases not. It's called skin effect and depends on frequency. At 50 Hz the skin depth of copper wire is 9,22 mm which means that the wire needs to be over 9,22*2 = 18,44 mm in diameter for skin effect to happen.

18,44 mm diameter is equal to 270 mm2 cross section. 270 mm2 copper wire is rated about 500A which is a HUGE current

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505878
Chisel the whole area out
Get some L shaped anchor bolts
Put them in the hole and align them as needed(you may have to use small nails and wire to hold them in place, or Blu tac/bubble gum)
Refill hole with hydraulic cement(may need to make a cast to catch the concrete or rotate house on it's side).
Wait appropriate amount of time then reattach railing.
Wa la, and make sure you chisel the hole so the hydraulic cement has something. To cling onto.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505878
Measure the holes exactly
Buy a wood dowel that's the same exact diameter
Cut 2 sections to slide in that are about flush with the outside
Put the screws back in

This will only work if it's concrete, cement filled block or solid masonry but it's 100% effective and how they have done it for centuries

>What happens if instead of conecting an air compressor to a pneumatic tool you conect a boiler
Residential steam boilers (for home heating) operate at less than 2psi. Even commercial steam boilers are under 15psi. You'd need a locomotive style boiler to get up to pressures that would be usable.
Even if you somehow managed to connect to a usable steam source you wouldn't be using your tool for long. The tool would get too hot to hold, the moisture would rust and corrode the guts, and the heat would melt the seals in the tool. I can only hope you're still holding it when the seals fail and the tool explodes.
Add to that the inefficiency of steam as a power source and the extreme cost of firing your boiler to the required temp and pressure.

tl;dr no you fucking mong

I may have misunderstood but... Do online paper wallets exist??
If so, how do I create an OFFLINE paper wallet??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
"online" and "offline" in this sense are really referring to the tool you use to document the private key for the public address.
Since most of these tools are online / web-based tools, the best practice is to save the tool/webpage locally, then disconnect from the internet, then use the tool to generate the key, then print the information.
If you're online when you do that, there's a chance that someone is observing you. If you're offline, the chance is reduced (unless you have some kind of keylogging malware on your computer).

He said it's a waste of time and money to do broke boi tek and that I would need a laminar flow hood and pressure cooker and all this lab stuff to properly grow shrooms, and he also said it's a waste of time to buy spore cultures and that I should get a spore print from a large fruit. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2512406
Mate if you only knew a tiny bit of chemistry you'd realize why you are wasting your time and energy in the long run.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2512546
Grain spawn is neat, and easy, and I'm grateful for having a workflow that works for me out in the boonies in my cabin, but I've never seen it used commercially in any context.

The "real" work I've done was all on pecan, pecan farm + mushroom farm + wood products producer (I still don't know what that really means).
We split felled pecan with the WPP based on appearance and cross-section, mostly they got the BIG FAT pieces we didn't want to work with.
The WPP produced this brown powder (which smelled absolutely amazing) that was, as I understand it, primarily lignin being produced from the tree bark, and we used a ton of that stuff.
In the time it would take for a little woodchip sample to be overrun with mycelium, you could fully impregnate massive quantities of the lignin powder mix with ease, which ultimately went on to dope nice chunks of pecan for growing a handful of different wood lovers.
Made lots of work quicker and easier, and I didn't experience any contamination in my time there, not even once; I definitely can't make that claim for my home setup.

threads.com: I work as an office wagie in a manufacturing environment, and I often work with engineers and our maintenance crew. I'm always impressed by maintenance's ability to keep absolute garbage machines going. I'm interested in what they do, and I'd like to expose myself to the skills they have. If I liked the style of work, I'd consider trying to become an apprentice. How could I expose myself to millwright-related skills that would make me more prepared to be an apprentice?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2511062
Take a machining course or a mechatronics course to begin with. Welding helps greatly. The reason for formal training is to speed up your early learning and expose you to theory of operation.

Many machinists become millwrights because the money is better. Talk to actual millwrights in your country to see what specific quals they want in a noob. There is no substitute for communication.

If serious ask if you can be a helper on night shift then stay late to learn. That makes you very impressive to any sane employer. I've done that several times to learn useful skills and it pays off.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509786
There were lots of small improvements made in the 1930s and 1940s when they were more widely used. Unfortunately it seems like most of the knowledge is spread out among communities that don't talk to each other.
For example, there are a few people in Sweden who drive gasifier-fueled cars, and every single one of them use a "stacked pancakes" fabric filter (a large "sock" that is tied off around wireframe discs; used to be canvas cloth in the 1940s, nowadays it's fibreglass). I've never seen for example Americans use fabric filters. Burgers all seem to use the Wayne Keith design, but the details are a trade secret and nobody outside of the US has heard of it.
The basics should be the same though, and there are some obvious things like insulating the hearth (firebox?) and using a heat exchanger for the air intake that I would do.
Another thing would be to convert a modern electric hybrid car. The pros and cons of a gasifier and a battery vehicle means they would complement each other pretty well.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2511970
Because the "T-shaped" one can accept 20A plugs (NEMA 5-20)

Your old one might have been rated to handle internally max 20A but only accept 15A plugs (NEMA 5-15).

Note that it's two outlets, so with the old one if you plug in two 15A loads in each outlet internally the outlet would be handling 30A and same goes for the wiring. So keep that 20A in mind and don't overload it.

threads.com:
I just bought this tool kit for 654USD$ after tax.
It was originally marked at 1200USD but its half off at home depot atm.
Did I do good? building up my tool collection.
I plan on buying wired versions of the skill saw and reciprocating hack saw at some point in my life too but I figured this kit was a good deal and I should go ahead and grab it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
avoid brushed if you can, especially for cordless tools. they use a lot more power.

i would recommend buying a few tools in one specific make/brand/lineup and expanding as-needed, and look for bundles that include batteries. when my wife and I moved-in together, she had an 18v Makita drill with 2 batteries... and that was it. Now we have two drills, plus an impact/hammer, oscillating multitool, flashlight and 10in saw and 5 batteries (some are 8 years old and still work great), including a bigass 5amp one. We use all of these frequently and they have each individually paid for themselves multiple times over in utility.

I assess the value of tools on an as-needed basis. For instance, wife and I needed a finishing nailgun in order to install some baseboards. Makita cordless one plus battery was something stupid like $199... for a tool we would maybe use a few times. For that cost, we got a 5gal air compressor (something i've wanted) and cheap nailgun that got the job done from harbor freight (lmao) for basically half the cost. Will probably seldom need it again, but it is there and it was cheap.

Yard tools are Ryobi. Quality is shit, old home owner left them with the house though so we use them... they work but they're like green plastic toys.

You can't really go wrong with DeWalt/Makita/Milwaukee. Once you get into one ecosystem though it makes sense to stick with it, so consider carefully before you dump $600 on brushed equipment that you might not like many years down the line. Better to get a few, good tools now and expand later.

It is not easy to cut an opening in log buildings, you have to stabilize the ends of the logs and you can not just nail a couple 2x10s in the opening and call it good. Generally you cut a mortise down the ends of the logs in the new opening and tenon in the framing for the door or at least stick a stud in the mortise which you attach the framing too. On a hot water heater that's spent 18 years on a well water system, the tank inside is probably comprised solely of rust. Any attempts to clean the tank, especially with rust removers, I would say is more likely to cause it to develop leaks than if you had just left it alone.

On a related note, if/when you go to replace it, if you're going to use another tank style heater get one of the non-metallic plastic ones (such as a Rheem Marathon) as they're far less susceptible to the rust/corrosion common with well water systems.

>>must add a quart of werewolf tears every six and a half moons otherwise the anaerobic ghost will come haunt you

Are you not doing this? Holy fuck.

What you're doing is essentially what my father did growing up. All forms of throwing your compostable stuff to the ground and letting it rot and dissolve into the earth is ok, but if you want to have a super-rich soil load every year, composting it in place is best. Turning it over is necessary and if you want to avoid concentrations of certain bacteria, you want to avoid tossing in fats and citrus and a few other things.

THAT said, I used an anaerobic compost barrel last year and produced EXCELLENT fertilizer by tossing all yard waste into a barrel of water and stirring once a week. Smells like an unwashed asshole, but when I applied it, I got the explosive growth I was promised. Additionally, I use an aerobic compost tumbler for my kitchen waste.

My garden kicks ass every year.

Sometimes doing the bare minimum is effective, but not the most beneficial.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509960
>>2510119
Unironically this is your solution.

Rack that folds up onto the wall, vertical plate storage and a barbell stand/wall hooks. Add on a folding weight bench and maybe a diy rolling adjustable dumbell cart (that also uses 2" olympic plates to minimize equipment) and you can fit your entire workout station in the space of a wardrobe.

For the workshop you buy/build a workbench with some casters on the feet so it can be rolled out of the way for the workout. Alternatively, have the workbench fold up/down against the wall via hinges, but this requires the bench be completely cleared off to move which is annoying.

For reference, I planned an olympic workout space + office space to fit into the 8'x7.25' section of a tinyhouse. My circumstances required a fair bit of custom made stuff to fit together like puzzle pieces for such a small space, but a few extra feet give you a lot more freedom for off-the-shelf equipment. Overhead and wall storage really help alleviate storage issues.

>I'm new to electronics. Where to get started?
It is an art/science of applying principles to requirements.
Find problem, learn principles, design and verify solution, build, test, post results, repeat.

>Incredibly comprehensive list of electronics resources:
https://github.com/kitspace/awesome-electronics
Additional resources below:

>Project ideas:
https://adafruit.com
https://instructables.com/tag/type-id/category-technology/
https://makezine.com/category/electronics/
https://hackaday.io

>Don't ask, roll:
https://github.com/Rocheez/4chan-electronics-challenges/blob/master/list-of-challenges.png

>Archive of Popular Electronics magazines (1954-2003):
https://worldradiohistory.com/Popular-Electronics-Guide.htm
>Microchip Tips and Tricks PDF:
https://ww1.microchip.com/downloads/en/devicedoc/01146b.pdf
>Li+/LiPo batteries required reading:
https://www.elteconline.com/download/pdf/SAFT-RIC-LI-ION-Safety-Recommendations.pdf

>Books:
https://libgen.rs/

>Principles (by increasing skill level):
Mims III, Getting Started in Electronics
Geier, How to Diagnose & Fix Everything Electronic
Kybett & Boysen, All New Electronics Self-Teaching Guide
Scherz & Monk, Practical Electronics for Inventors (arguably has minor issues with mains grounding)
Horowitz and Hill, The Art of Electronics

>Recommended Design/verification tools:
KiCAD 6+
Circuitmaker
Logisim Evolution

>Recommended Components/equipment:
Octopart
eBay/AliExpress sellers, for component assortments/sample kits (caveat emptor)

threads.com: I’m going to be doing some work 20ft up in the air on the side of this guys house. I have an extension ladder. What are some dos and don’ts of using an extension ladder safely??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510166
I've always stuck by the rule that the acceptable diagonal slope is determined by
this:
Stand with your lowest rung touching your legs. Reach out with your arms, and if the ladder is farther than your arms are long, it's too far slanted. If it's closer than your elbow it's too straight.
ALWAYS have one hand on a rung
been painting exteriors for 10+ years and I've never fallen off a ladder (skipping the last rung going down doesn't count :) )

Make sure feet of ladder are secured, and that both the left and the right of the top of the ladder are bracing against something sturdy
(as opposed to either side dangling in the air) Yes, I've seen it happen with some cheap ass fucks
Never ever ever put ladder against windows

To test ladder won't fall away from you on a hill,
put it down the way you want, step up one to two rungs, then jump a few times putting your entire weight on to see if it moves.
Let someone know you're on a ladder so they can be nearby if you fall.

I have an ancient gas oven that's set up to run on a propane tank out back. The stovetop works but the oven part does not. Everything in it is mechanical except the clock and the spark wires that light the gas, so it's not an electrical problem. The gas flow is good enough to light all four stovetop burners on full blast simultaneously.
Inside, when I turn on the oven, it clicks and lights the pilot. The pilot flame comes on after a concerningly long amount of clicking (which I attribute to mice chewing on the wires to the spark), but the rest of the pipe never lights. It is equipped with a mercury capillary-driven safety valve with a bulb over the pilot light, so if the pilot goes out the gas will stop. I have confirmed the safety valve works by removing it, holding a lighter to the bulb, and blowing through where the propane goes. After about 10 seconds of heat on the bulb I can feel it suddenly open up and air comes out where it's meant to. The main pipe the oven flames are supposed to come from is not clogged, it's not even dirty.
It does have a regulator on the back, which I have never touched. I've read online that in many cases the regulator is just for the oven part and if it fails the stovetop will still work. How can I test if the regulator is bad without buying a new one, since it's practically antique? I am soliciting any other ideas for what could be wrong with this thing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507231
Besides regulator you need different nozzles for natural gas and propane gas.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508340
LP gas requires a minimum of 10"wc (that's water column, NOT psi) inlet pressure and should be set to somewhere in the neighborhood of 7"wc output.

If this was originally a natural gas stove then it would also require you to change all of the burner orifices and the pilot orifice. Natural gas orifices are larger and allow more gas flow, if you put LP through them at the correct pressure it will seriously overfire and soot up. Good luck finding LP orifices for a stove since they usually are made for a specific gas and the mfg doesn't sell conversion kits.

tl;dr pressure too low cause you eyeballed it

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510963
>I'm sure there's a use case, I'm just curious what it is.
You hit it here:
>Or are they normally used in a tiered system to provide instant power while a generator comes online?
And reduced maintenance costs. Even a pre-heated, continuously oiled, air start diesel generator has a non trivial time between the call for backup electricity and the ability to accept 100% of the rated load. As an example, nuclear plants that use literal train engines as their back-up power source when there is a loss-of-offsite-power plan for 15-45 seconds of time between the reactor trip and the diesel engines picking up all the house loads at 100%. Everything that needs to stay up during the transient is on a UPS. They are also one of the most maintenance intensive items in a nuclear plant.

>>2507235
Put on forcefield or zip system sheathing
Then if you're north of Missouri, nail on 2x2s and put 1.5" foam insulation in-between the nailers

Then side with cement siding for sound dampening or vinyl with a smaller slat so it's 0 maintenance

You want to put on sheathing to hold the house square, which acts as a moisture barrier for comfort in the home and then a wind barrier (the film on the outside of the sheathing) which also allows condensation to run down

The 1.5" of insulation will ensure minimal condensation inside the house.
If you're doing a moisture barrier inside, then a moisture barrier outside (plain plywood/OSB technically counts) is SUPER FUCKING IMPORTANT or your walls will rot after 3 years

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510771
Reason not to do this is that a beat to shit poorly maintained rental with 300k on it would be a nightmare to fix and maintain. I used to drive Ryder trucks when my fleet truck was cooked and let me tell you, those gears were sooo fucking sloppy and they always had something leaking. If it's based off a platform with continuing support replacing drivetrain is a option though.

Personally if I was going to get a ex-fleet vehicle to live in, I'd pick a school bus. Lots more space than 26ft box truck, has built in man doors. Very strong bodies, busses are designed to keep unbelted children safe when they get t-boned. Depending on district most places cycle busses out when they hit 300k or when they hit 20~ years of age, typically age first if it's inner city, those machines don't travel far. Ritzy private schools often cycle them out much quicker, not uncommon to see a 10y/o bus with 80-k on the clock up for auction. License is dead easy to get, if you're too dumb to get it you're too retarded to DIY a place to live. Most of them are autos which saves them from most user error/abuse, all have commonly available diesel engines like caterpillar, detroit, etc. so ANY diesel shop can fix em if you can't. Worst case scenario you can drop in a new engine/trans of ANY brand, the bodies and drive trains are made separately then assembled when a fleet orders o there's a lot of interoperability, whether new new or from a wrecked big rig, box truck or school bus. Most have air brakes though, I personally prefer air brakes for a large commercial-sized vehicle for the reliability and backup they offer, but if that's a sticking point for you some districts use hydraulics. Buy one from a area that doesn't get real winters IE Arizona to limit rust. If you're in a area that gets winter have her undercoated and keep it clean and the body will last forever.

>t. used to drive school busses, currently drive big rigs. North American perspective, no idea about down under
